messageBody:
> I learned about the class loader issue a year ago. The instant I have
> a wierd problem with a test, I run it twice, once under swingui and again
> with textui.
>
> If it runs under textui but not swingui, my next step is to add -noloading
> to swingui. That has always solved the problem, and -noloading goes
> right into the project's launcher from that point onward.
>
> This loading/noloading trick is necessary for JNI debugging as well,
> because with JNI the JVM will load a library at most once, no matter
> what classloader is involved.

Useful trick to know... We wrote our own test runner. It extends
junit.runner.BaseTestRunner. The default behavior of BaseTestRunner is to
use the custom class loader. I think that's counter-intuitive. Anyone who
writes their own runner will have to learn about the custom class loader the
hard way.

> I have no difficulties with the current default behavior. The GUI
> interfaces, which you like to leave up and running, must obviously
> be using the custom classloader, because otherwise you're just restesting
> old classes already in the JVM. TextUI doesn't stay running and doesn't
> take long to load, so it doesn't use the custom classloader.

You think correctly - the GUIs should reload, the others should not.

Thanks,

_chas_
